Allan Knight Chalmers, Minister
of the Broadway tabernacle in New
York city and alumnus of the Johns
Hopkins university, will address the
University Supper club next Tuesday.
He will be the third speaker in the
series.
Dr Chalmers is widely known for
his leadership in the peace movement. He is a member of the Delta
Upsilon and Omicron Delta Kappa
fraternities.

that he will talk on some phase of
the peace movement. He was instrumental in organizing the New York
ministers peace group meeting at the
Riverside church in May 1935, and
helped promote its recent meeting in
March at the Broadway tabernacle.

the Scottsboro Defense committee
which has been instrumental in freeing four of the colored youths in the

the United States to tht Oxford conference on Life and Work, and has

Advance, the Christian Century, the
Pulpit, the Pilgrim Highroad, the

Elections for two positions on the
Hullabaloo staff, held yesterday resulted in the election of Albert Rosenthal as junior business manager and
a tie between Robert Hoopes and
Alan Hecht for the position of junior
editor.

decide on the junior editor," Theodore M Schad, editor-in-chief of the
year book, announced. "The new election will take place Friday at 12.30
in the Sherwood room, Levering hall."
An announcement that all proofs
of pictures taken for the Hullabaloo
must be returned on Friday, December 1, between 9 and 5 was issued
yesterday.

athletic policy

One of the most radical steps in
the history of athletics was taken last
week at St John's College when
Stringfellow Barr, president of the
college, announced the discontinuance of intercollegiate athletics.
The new plan features an extended system of intramural sports including such extreme fields of athletic endeavor as squash and sailing.
In his statement president Barr
asserted: "The term athletic scholarship is used widely today to hide
subsidy and professionalism. Athletic scholarships are granted by many
colleges with a good deal of hypocritical talk about Rhodes scholarships, high grades, fine character,
eligibility, etc., but for the obvious
purpose of providing teams with
paid players to win games."
The new plan provides for athletic
scholarship which the athletes are
awarded not for competition on representative teams, but for their assistance in teaching sports to other
students. The change in policy also
brought the resignation of present
coaches Valentine (Dutch) Lentz and
John C Donohue. Barr praised the
two coaches for their recent extensive development of intramural sports
which made it possible to complete
the new plans.
Barr expressed the sentiment that
the new plan would not decrease the
interest in athletics. "Fear may be
expressed that dropping intercollegiate athletics will kill interest in all
athletics. This fear seems to be
groundless. There are two kinds of
interest in athletics, the interest a
good player feels in playing well, and
the interest a 'popular athlete' feels
in attracting applause. We want and
expect at St John's a great deal of
the first kind of interest but exhibitionism does not interest us."

athletic policy

One of the most radical steps in
the history of athletics was taken last
week at St John's College when
Stringfellow Barr, president of the
college, announced the discontinuance of intercollegiate athletics.
The new plan features an extended system of intramural sports including such extreme fields of athletic endeavor as squash and sailing.
In his statement president Barr
asserted: "The term athletic scholarship is used widely today to hide
subsidy and professionalism. Athletic scholarships are granted by many
colleges with a good deal of hypocritical talk about Rhodes scholarships, high grades, fine character,
eligibility, etc., but for the obvious
purpose of providing teams with
paid players to win games."
The new plan provides for athletic
scholarship which the athletes are
awarded not for competition on representative teams, but for their assistance in teaching sports to other
students. The change in policy also
brought the resignation of present
coaches Valentine (Dutch) Lentz and
John C Donohue. Barr praised the
two coaches for their recent extensive development of intramural sports
which made it possible to complete
the new plans.
Barr expressed the sentiment that
the new plan would not decrease the
interest in athletics. "Fear may be
expressed that dropping intercollegiate athletics will kill interest in all
athletics. This fear seems to be
groundless. There are two kinds of
interest in athletics, the interest a
good player feels in playing well, and
the interest a 'popular athlete' feels
in attracting applause. We want and
expect at St John's a great deal of
the first kind of interest but exhibitionism does not interest us."
